unnormalised: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has issued a circular mandating the linking of Permanent Account Numbers (PAN) to all Know Your Customer (KYC) compliant bank accounts by 31/12/2024. This directive aims to enhance transparency and prevent financial irregularities across the Indian banking sector. Account holders who fail to comply with this regulation may face restrictions on their accounts, including limitations on transactions and eventual freezing of accounts until the necessary linking is completed. The RBI emphasizes that this measure is crucial for curbing money laundering and other illicit financial activities.
normalised: The Reserve Bank of India (R-B-I) has issued a circular mandating the linking of Permanent Account Numbers (P-A-N) to all Know Your Customer (K-Y-C) compliant bank accounts by thirty first december two thousand and twenty four. This directive aims to enhance transparency and prevent financial irregularities across the Indian banking sector. Account holders who fail to comply with this regulation may face restrictions on their accounts, including limitations on transactions and eventual freezing of accounts until the necessary linking is completed. The R-B-I emphasizes that this measure is crucial for curbing money laundering and other illicit financial activities.

unnormalised: According to the circular, all existing bank customers are required to provide their PAN details to their respective banks. New account openings will necessitate immediate PAN verification during the KYC process. Banks are instructed to prominently display notices regarding this mandatory linking, ensuring customers are well-informed and have sufficient time to complete the process. The linking can typically be done online through the bank's internet banking portal or mobile application, or offline by submitting a copy of the PAN card at the bank branch.

New account openings will necessitate immediate P-A-N verification during the K-Y-C process. Banks are instructed to prominently display notices regarding this mandatory linking, ensuring customers are well-informed and have sufficient time to complete the process. The linking can typically be done online through the bank's internet banking portal or mobile application, or offline by submitting a copy of the P-A-N card at the bank branch.

unnormalised: This initiative is part of a broader effort by the Indian government to improve financial accountability and track financial transactions effectively. The Income Tax Department plays a crucial role in verifying the PAN details submitted by account holders, ensuring accuracy and preventing fraudulent submissions. Any discrepancies found during the verification process must be promptly rectified by the account holder to avoid any adverse consequences.

unnormalised: The RBI has also clarified that certain categories of accounts, such as Basic Savings Bank Deposit Accounts (BSBDA) and accounts held by senior citizens who do not have a PAN, may be exempted from this mandatory linking requirement. However, such exemptions are subject to specific conditions and require appropriate documentation to be submitted to the bank for verification. Banks are tasked with guiding customers on the applicable exemptions and ensuring that eligible customers are not unduly burdened by this regulation.

unnormalised: The implementation of this PAN linking mandate is expected to significantly enhance the effectiveness of financial monitoring and reporting systems. By creating a centralized database of PAN-linked bank accounts, regulatory authorities will be better equipped to detect and prevent financial crimes, contributing to a more secure and stable financial environment in India. The RBI urges all stakeholders, including banks, account holders, and regulatory agencies, to cooperate fully in the implementation of this important initiative.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the circular outlines specific procedures for banks to follow in cases where multiple accounts are linked to the same PAN. Banks are required to conduct thorough due diligence to ensure that such accounts are not being used for any illegal purposes. Any suspicious activity detected in these accounts must be immediately reported to the relevant authorities, in accordance with the existing guidelines on anti-money laundering (AML) and combating the financing of terrorism (CFT).

unnormalised: The RBI has indicated that it will closely monitor the progress of this PAN linking initiative and may issue further instructions or clarifications as needed. Banks are expected to maintain detailed records of all PAN-linked accounts and to provide regular reports to the RBI on the status of their compliance. Failure to comply with this mandate may result in penalties or other enforcement actions by the RBI. The central bank reiterates its commitment to maintaining the integrity and stability of the Indian banking system through effective regulatory measures and proactive enforcement. Account holders can contact their bank's customer service or visit the nearest branch for assistance with PAN linking. Banks like SBI, HDFC Bank, ICICI Bank and PNB have already provided detailed instructions on their websites regarding this.
